articles.headline: Gadgets to Help Tend a Garden
articles.snippet: A drone to scare away deer? A device in the soil that sends a message when it needs water? Those are some of the devices to help your flowers and vegetables flourish.
articles.abstract: A drone to scare away deer? A device in the soil that sends a message when it needs water? Those are some of the devices to help your flowers and vegetables flourish.
articles.lead_paragraph: Picture a tiny drone that arises from your vegetable garden to shoo away hungry deer. Or maybe a houseplant that, when you’re away, meanders through your rooms like a cat following a sunbeam. Or one that posts a request for water on Twitter.
articles.byline: By Roxie Hammill and Mike Hendricks

articles.headline: Down Payment Rules Are at Heart of Mortgage Debate
articles.snippet: Many lawmakers, lenders and consumer advocates are now cautioning against rules that would require many borrowers to make large down payments.
articles.abstract: Many lawmakers, lenders and consumer advocates are now cautioning against rules that would require many borrowers to make large down payments.
articles.lead_paragraph: It seemed an easy fix to prevent the excesses of the housing market: make home buyers put more money down.

articles.headline: By 2023, a Changed World in Energy
articles.snippet: The year 2023 could find more use of solar power, wind and natural gas, and the United States could be a major oil exporter.
articles.abstract: The year 2023 could find more use of solar power, wind and natural gas, and the United States could be a major oil exporter.

articles.headline: New Technology Inspires a Rethinking of Light
articles.snippet: Beyond the energy and cost savings, new types of lighting are now envisioned as ways to heal, soothe, invigorate or protect people.
articles.abstract: Beyond the energy and cost savings, new types of lighting are now envisioned as ways to heal, soothe, invigorate or protect people.
articles.lead_paragraph: AFTER the joy of the birth itself, parenthood sometimes brings the unwelcome news that a newborn has jaundice and must wear goggles and be placed under special lights. Imagine how different this experience might be if there were no goggles, just a warm blanket covering the tiny body, a healing frequency of blue light emanating from its folds.

articles.headline: Joint Effort Seeks Drugs for Autism
articles.snippet: The University of California will lead a $9 million effort financed by the National Institute of Mental Health to identify promising drugs for autism and conduct early tests.
articles.abstract: The University of California will lead a $9 million effort financed by the National Institute of Mental Health to identify promising drugs for autism and conduct early tests.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the diagnosis of autism on the rise and drug companies facing major setbacks in developing successful treatments, the University of California, Los Angeles will lead a $9 million effort financed by the National Institute of Mental Health to find effective drugs, officials said Wednesday.

articles.headline: Updating an E-Mail Law From the Last Century
articles.snippet: An overhauling by Congress would require that search warrants be obtained for all personal e-mails and other electronic content held by a third-party service provider.
articles.abstract: An overhauling by Congress would require that search warrants be obtained for all personal e-mails and other electronic content held by a third-party service provider.
articles.lead_paragraph: Steven Warshak, a Cincinnati businessman who built an empire selling male sexual enhancement drugs, was convicted of wire fraud several years ago, based in large part on his e-mail correspondence, which authorities had extracted via a subpoena under a 1986 law governing electronic privacy.

articles.headline: Despair Drives Guantánamo Detainees to Revolt
articles.snippet: With any decision about closing down the prison in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, put on the back burner, inmates there have lost hope that they will ever be released.
articles.abstract: With any decision about closing down the prison in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, put on the back burner, inmates there have lost hope that they will ever be released.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — In the early afternoon quiet, guards in camouflage fatigues walked the two-tiered cellblocks of Camp Six, where the most cooperative of the 166 terrorism suspects held in the military prison here are housed. From a darkened control room, other guards watched banks of surveillance monitors showing prisoners in white clothing — pacing, sleeping or reading — in their cells.

articles.headline: Streaming on Yahoo, It’s ‘S.N.L.’
articles.snippet: The Internet company signed a deal for exclusive streaming rights to past episodes of “Saturday Night Live” to gain an edge in a small market for digital video advertising.
articles.abstract: The Internet company signed a deal for exclusive streaming rights to past episodes of “Saturday Night Live” to gain an edge in a small market for digital video advertising.
articles.lead_paragraph: When they were performing on “Saturday Night Live” three decades ago, Al Franken, Bill Murray and Eddie Murphy surely didn’t expect they would ever be streamed on computers and phones. In fact, they probably would have made fun of the idea.

articles.headline: Officer’s Killing Spurred Pursuit in Boston Attack
articles.snippet: The shooting of Officer Sean A. Collier was the first bloody altercation in a chain of events that ended with one suspect in the Boston bombings captured and the other dead.
articles.abstract: The shooting of Officer Sean A. Collier was the first bloody altercation in a chain of events that ended with one suspect in the Boston bombings captured and the other dead.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Officer Sean A. Collier was 27, not much older than the Massachusetts Institute of Technology students he watched over as a campus police officer, and he sometimes joined them in a game of darts or Xbox. So when an ambulance staffed by students rolled past his parked patrol car last Thursday night, he flashed his blue lights to say hello. The students answered with their red lights.
articles.byline: By Wendy Ruderman, Serge F. Kovaleski and Michael Cooper

articles.headline: Possible Fed Successor Has Admirers and Foes
articles.snippet: Janet L. Yellen is seen as a logical candidate to succeed the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, but critics remain wary of her stance on inflation.
articles.abstract: Janet L. Yellen is seen as a logical candidate to succeed the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, but critics remain wary of her stance on inflation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In July 1996, the Federal Reserve broke the metronomic routine of its closed-door policy-making meetings to hold an unusual debate. The Fed’s powerful chairman, Alan Greenspan, saw a chance for the first time in decades to drive annual inflation all the way down to zero, achieving the price stability he had long regarded as the central bank’s primary mission.

articles.headline: Syria Plays on Fears to Blunt American Support of Rebels
articles.snippet: As Islamists increasingly fill the ranks of Syrian rebels, President Bashar al-Assad is waging an energized campaign to persuade the United States that it is on the wrong side of the war.
articles.abstract: As Islamists increasingly fill the ranks of Syrian rebels, President Bashar al-Assad is waging an energized campaign to persuade the United States that it is on the wrong side of the war.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Syria — As Islamists increasingly fill the ranks of Syrian rebels, President Bashar al-Assad is waging an energized campaign to persuade the United States that it is on the wrong side of the civil war. Some government supporters and officials believe they are already coaxing — or at least frightening — the West into holding back stronger support for the opposition.

articles.headline: Western Firms Feel Pressure as Toll Rises in Bangladesh
articles.snippet: With more than 250 people dead, a collapsed building’s owner was in hiding and pressure was building on companies that had pledged steps to ensure the safety of Bangladeshi factories.
articles.abstract: With more than 250 people dead, a collapsed building’s owner was in hiding and pressure was building on companies that had pledged steps to ensure the safety of Bangladeshi factories.
articles.lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — As rescuers struggled on Thursday to reach survivors in one of the worst manufacturing disasters in history, pointed questions were being raised about why a Bangladesh factory building was not padlocked after terrified workers notified the police, government officials and a powerful garment industry group about cracks in the walls.
articles.byline: By Julfikar Ali Manik, Steven Greenhouse and Jim Yardley

articles.headline: Doctors Denounce Cancer Drug Prices of $100,000 a Year
articles.snippet: More than 100 influential cancer specialists argued in a journal that some drug prices are unsustainable and perhaps even immoral.
articles.abstract: More than 100 influential cancer specialists argued in a journal that some drug prices are unsustainable and perhaps even immoral.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the cost of some lifesaving cancer drugs exceeding $100,000 a year, more than 100 influential cancer specialists from around the world have taken the unusual step of banding together in hopes of persuading some leading pharmaceutical companies to bring prices down.
